title: First picture of lorry driver arrested after 39 bodies discovered in Essex
text:
Mo Robinson is believed to have been arrested in Essex this morning

The first picture has emerged of the lorry driver believed to have been arrested by police after 39 bodies were found in a lorry.

The man has been named locally as Mo Robinson, a 25-year-old from Portadown, Northern Ireland.

He is being held on suspicion of murder after the grim discovery at Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex, at 1.40am this morning.

Mr Robinson may have picked up the refrigerated container in Essex just minutes before the bodies were found inside.

He is believed to have driven the tractor unit from Northern Ireland over the weekend and collected the trailer from Essex late last night.

A major murder investigation has been launched (Picture: PA)

Police activity at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex (Picture: PA)

Detectives believe the trailer travelled from Zebrugge, Belgium, into the port of Purfleet.

It then docked in the Thurrock are at around 12.30am local time and stopped for around 35 minutes.

CCTV footage shows Mr Robinson driving into the industrial estate at 1.10am and the police were called around half an hour later.

The origin of the container before it got to Zeebrugge is not known.

The 39 people on board who died included at least one teenager.

Mo Robinson has been named as the arrested lorry driver

Police activity at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex (Picture: PA)

Mr Robinson’s Facebook page shows a number of lorries, including him sitting in the cab.

There is also an image of what appears to be the cab that was photographed at the scene in Essex on Wednesday.

It has an identical sticker that reads ‘The Ultimate Dream’ on the windscreen.

His social media posts show that he makes frequent trips to Sweden and Denmark.

Mr Robinson’s family told BelfastLive that they had not spoken to Mr Robinson since reports broke of the bodies being found.

His partner’s visibly shaken brother said they hadn’t ‘heard from him’ and ‘don’t know what is going on.’

It is understood that Mr Robinson does not own the lorry and that it is registered in the port city of Varna, Bulgaria, to an Irish company.

Mo Robinson has posted on social media images of the lorries he drives

The horrific find has sparked one of the biggest murder investigations in British history – and was described by Essex Police as an ‘absolute tragedy’.

Advertisement

Officials believe it is a case of human trafficking because of the way the bodies were found.

Police said the people have not yet been identified and the lorry will be moved shortly.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he was ‘appalled by this tragic incident’, while local Tory MP Jackie Doyle-Price said ‘people trafficking is a vile and dangerous business.’

This story is breaking and will be updated.
